items.title: Indonesia vows to stay ‘active’ in global sport despite IOC backlash over Israel ban
items.summary: Indonesia says it won’t be sidelined from world sport after the IOC urged federations to stop hosting events there in response to its ban on Israeli gymnasts.

items.title: Escape. Hide. Tell. Staying safe in a terrorist attack
items.summary: Counter-terrorism police forces across Australia have launched a new campaign that aims to educate people about how to protect themselves in the event of an armed attack. Authorities say Australia is at risk from weapons attacks, especially in crowded places, while the country's terror threat level remains at probable.

items.title: Optus executives step down as triple-zero disaster fallout continues
items.summary: The announcement didn’t suggest the departures were related to a recent Optus triple-zero outage, which has been linked to three deaths.

items.title: Albo, Trump and the elephant in the room, Gaza ceasefire fractures & a very French heist
items.summary: In this episode: Behind the scenes of Prime Minister Anthony Albanese’s highly anticipated meeting with US President Donald Trump, while Ukraine’s leader Vlodymyr Zelenskyy walks away from the White House without his Tomahawk missiles. Plus, more threats to the Gaza ceasefire despite optimism from US Vice President JD Vance, the ‘high-stakes’ meeting between the Australian and Indonesian military chiefs, and how a daring daylight robbery unfolded at the Louvre.

items.title: Greens raise alarm over new environment laws | Evening News Bulletin 23 October 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, the Greens raise concerns over a key feature of the government's new environment laws, the opposition to bring a personal income tax cut policy to the next election. And in gymnastics, Liverpool makes a bid to host the 2030 World Championships, as Britain rises in the sport.

items.title: Hastie joins Coalition voices backing Rudd, breaking with Ley

items.title: Israel ordered to allow aid into Gaza, ICJ rules
items.summary: The International Court of Justice has issued an advisory opinion, stating that as the occupying power, Israel has failed to provide adequate humanitarian supplies to Gaza’s civilian population. The Israeli parliament has just narrowly approved a preliminary bill to apply Israeli civil law to the occupied West Bank, a move viewed internationally as a step towards annexation.

items.summary: In this bulletin, Donald Trump announces new sanctions on major Russian oil companies, Sydney to hit a 2 million-dollar median house price, by the end of next year. And in cricket, Australia wins against England in Women's World Cup.

items.title: Japan's Sanae Takaichi makes history but will it change things for Japanese women?

Japan's first female Prime Minister: an 'Iron Lady' with tough tasks ahead
items.summary: Japan's newly elected Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi has promised to "work like a horse" to get the country back on track. As the country's first female Prime Minister, Ms Takaichi will have to deal with the growing domestic dissatisfaction over economy, wages and cost of living.

items.title: Australian-PNG defence treaty: 'one big fence securing two houses'
items.summary: The 31st Australia-Papua New Guinea Ministerial Forum was hosted in Canberra on Monday [[Oct 20]], focusing on the implementation of the historic mutual defence treaty signed between the two countries earlier this month. The 'puk-puk' treaty will see Australia invest millions of dollars in the PNG defence force. A key part of the deal is a taskforce to recruit PNG citizens into the Australian Defence Force, but this has been criticized by former PNG defence personnel who claim the pact is harmful because PNG does not share Australia's fear of China.

items.title: Investor warning about FOMO as gold stocks tumble
items.summary: The gold price has seen its worst one day fall in 12 years as gold stocks tumble after their recent run. Similarly, rare earths also slide. SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Cameron Gleeson from Betashares and Scott Phillips from The Motley Fool to find out why some investors are pressing the sell button and offers a reality check.

items.title: Gaza ceasefire going 'better than expected', JD Vance says on Israel trip
items.summary: More than a week into the Gaza ceasefire, senior US officials have visited Israel to discuss ways to progress to the next stage of Donald Trump's 20-point peace plan. Flareups of violence in recent days has threatened to unravel the ceasefire. Meanwhile, the United Nations says it is important the ceasefire holds - to allow for aid deliveries to be scaled up in Gaza.

items.summary: Diplomacy has overtaken the battlefield in the Ukraine war, with Washington, Moscow, and Kyiv offering starkly different paths to peace. The Kremlin says no Trump-Putin summit date is set, while Washington insists leverage not concessions will end the war.

items.title: Breastfeeding reduces the risk of breast cancer, researchers say
items.summary: Australian researchers have found breastfeeding can protect women against breast cancer by building up their immunity. According to a new study, pregnancy and breastfeeding produces infection-fighting T-cells that help guard against abnormal cells that could develop into cancer.

items.title: Sarkozy begins his prison sentence in France - still maintaining his innocence
items.summary: The former President of France, Nicholas Sarkozy, has begun his 5-year prison sentence, becoming the first French leader to be jailed since World War Two. He was convicted of a criminal conspiracy to finance his election campaign with funds from a Libyan dictator. The 70 year is appealing the decision, claiming the case was politically motivated.

items.title: Rare earths deal boosts some mining shares as ASX hits record
items.summary: The Australian sharemarket hit a record high for a second time in a week as the US and Australia strike a rare earths supply deal, but it was BHP that was a real stand out today. SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Catherine Allfrey from Wavestone Capital to find out if the sector is worth the hype and what else is driving investors.

items.title: Deals signed as Trump and Albanese meet; but what are the wider implications?
items.summary: In a historic meeting between Donald Trump and Anthony Albanese, the AUKUS agreement remained unchanged as the two leaders unveiled a multi-billion-dollar critical minerals deal to secure supply chains and reduce reliance on China. The agreement involves major US investment in Australian mining and processing projects, but has sparked criticism over fears it could give the US too much control over Australia’s resources and sovereignty.

items.title: 'Broke half the internet': Amazon cloud outage lasts 15 hours, triggering global chaos
items.summary: A massive internet outage has taken out thousands of websites, apps and services globally. The technical fault originated with U-S data centres operated by Amazon Web Services, which controls 30 per cent of the world's cloud computing market that underpins web-based services like apps and websites.

items.title: How caring in language can prevent elderly falls
items.summary: In Australia, around one in four people aged over 65 experiences at least one fall each year and it is the leading cause of injury, hospitalisation, and death among older Australians. Preventing falls isn’t simple, especially when language stands in the way of awareness. But in Perth, two Chinese university students are turning that challenge into change, using their culture and compassion to protect some of those most vulnerable.

items.title: Barking bad: The ruff road to recovery

items.title: Long-lost diary tells a personal story of China's involvement in D-Day
items.summary: A long-lost diary from a Chinese war veteran has been discovered, detailing the participation of China's participation in D-Day. The 80-page diary was discovered in an abandoned Hong Kong flat, and details Lam Ping Yu's brush with death during the world's largest-ever sea, land and air armada on D Day during World War Two.

items.title: Fears grow over truce's fragility amid concerns around hostages bodies, aid

This comes as satellite images show limited aid convoys entering the enclave through Kerem Shalom, while displaced Palestinians in Khan Younis endure worsening living conditions amid shortages of food, fuel, and clean water. With more than 67,900 Palestinians killed since 2023 and uncertainty over Rafah’s reopening, fears are growing that the fragile truce could collapse.

items.summary: A key border crossing between Gaza and Egypt will remain closed, dashing hopes it would quickly open under a ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas.

items.title: SPECIAL EPISODE: Inside the Gaza ceasefire: hostages, prisoners & a negotiator
items.summary: Israeli hostages have been released and Palestinians prisoners freed, but is the Trump-brokered truce a turning point or just a timeout? This in-depth episode explores the deal, the delivery of aid, and the future of Gaza.

items.title: The great divide: Australians reach a 'difficult' new high
items.summary: Some say the numbers show life is getting harder, while others argue the picture isn’t as "dire" as it seems.

items.title: ASX hits record as jobless rate rises to 4.5%
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Chris Brycki from Stockspot while Stephanie Youseff talks with Alex Joiner from IFM Investors about the rise in the unemployment rate to a near four year high, what it means for interest rates and why the sharemarket hit a record as a result.

items.title: Yeah, nah: Australians report a drop in their sense of belonging
items.summary: Australians' sense of belonging has been declining over time. That's the major finding from this year's social cohesion report, from the Scanlon Foundation Research Institute. But while the report suggests there is ongoing strain in peoples' sense of belonging, trust, and identity, the Foundation remains optimistic, saying most Australians still report happiness and a strong sense of community.

items.title: 'Degraded and uneasy': Incarcerated trans women push back on NT prison ban proposal
items.summary: Trans women prisoners are most at risk of violence, advocates say, hitting back at the NT chief minister's recent claims.

items.title: Government could make offshore skills change to solve 'wicked' problem
items.summary: Proposed tweaks to the skilled migration pathway could ensure migrants arrive job-ready.

items.title: Army vehicle fleet grounded after soldier killed during training rollover in Queensland
items.summary: The soldier died after the M113 armoured personnel carrier he was travelling in rolled west of Townsville about 6.30pm on Wednesday.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 16 October
items.summary: A daily five-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Germany, NATO pledge billions in new Ukraine aid as Russia reels from fuel strikes
items.summary: Germany and NATO allies have pledged billions in new aid to Ukraine as the war nears its fourth winter, with Kyiv urging urgent air-defence support amid a sharp drop in foreign assistance. Meanwhile, Russia is grappling with fuel shortages following Ukrainian strikes, as President Donald Trump renews his criticism of Vladimir Putin over the prolonged conflict and Russia’s faltering economy.

items.title: Hamas-Israel ceasefire holds - but only just
items.summary: Two more bodies of deceased hostages have been handed over to the Red Cross by Hamas, following Israel's accusation that the militant group were failing to abide by the terms of the ceasefire deal. Aid is continuing to roll into Gaza despite threats from Israel that they would cut supplies and close border crossings. But there are heightened concerns for the fragile ceasefire, amid reports US President Donald Trump is considering allowing Israel to resume its military activities.

items.title: Trump confirms he authorised covert CIA operations in Venezuela
items.summary: Donald Trump said he was "looking at land now" after recently targeting alleged drug smuggling boats from Venezuela by sea.

items.title: Is your job burning you out? Experts say better boundaries and workplace connections can help
items.summary: Despite a growing awareness around mental health, research shows burnout in the workplace is still a major challenge. Experts say without proper training and healthy boundaries in the workplace, more and more Australians will consider leaving their jobs in the next year.

items.title: Madagascar braces for military rule as coup leader prepares to be sworn in
items.summary: The African Union said it was suspending Madagascar after a coup ousted President Andry Rajoelina.

items.title: Madagascar braces for military rule as coup leader prepares to be sworn in
items.summary: The African Union said it was suspending Madagascar after a coup ousted President Andry Rajoelina.

items.title: Hamas says it can't retrieve more bodies, as first hostage funerals start in Israel
items.summary: Israel confirmed it had received the coffins of two more deceased hostages and was transporting them to a facility for identification.

items.title: Young people feel much more disconnected than boomers in Australia. Why?
items.summary: Social isolation and economic disadvantage are partly responsible for declining rates in national belonging, a new study suggests.

items.title: Australia's rainforests are now adding to carbon emissions, scientists say
items.summary: A new study has found Queensland's tropical rainforests emit more carbon than they absorb, raising concerns for Australia's climate targets.

items.title: NSW hits 'grim milestone' with First Nations deaths in custody reaching record levels
items.summary: The New South Wales coroner says the state has hit a grim milestone with First Nations deaths in custody reaching record levels. 12 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have died in custody in the state this year, the highest number ever recorded in a single year. The distressing figures have prompted the state coroner to issue a rare public statement, condemning the deaths and vowing to investigate each one independently and thoroughly.

items.title: Labor criticised over worker visa rule backflip that could affect thousands
items.summary: Tens of thousands of people from the Pacific and East Timor currently work in Australia under the PALM scheme.

items.title: The 'confluence of crises' driving Australia's record-low fertility rate
items.summary: Australia's birth rate is declining — but researchers say it's "not about selfishness".

items.title: What record low fertility rates mean for our economy & gold hits another record
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with McCrindle Social Researcher Ashley Fell about thegrowing trend for Australians to have fewer kids, and later in life; plus Luke Laretive from Seneca Financial Services looks through the day's sharemarket moves including what he is telling his clients.

items.title: Kathryn lost her banking job to a chatbot. She just confronted her CBA bosses
items.summary: Former Commonwealth Bank employee Kathryn Sullivan spent years teaching the bank's "Bumblebee" chatbot how to respond to customers.

items.title: These Sydneysiders watched as the hostage-detainee swap played out. Then came a call
items.summary: Palestinian and Jewish Australians describe their emotional journey watching the first phase of the Gaza ceasefire.

items.title: Israel and Hamas both accused of not keeping cease fire agreement
items.summary: Hamas has returned more bodies of Israeli hostages to the International Committee of the Red Cross in Gaza. Questions remain over sustainable peace in the Middle East, with uncertainty about how to resolve sticking points in Donald Trump's 20-point plan.

items.title: Socceroos' undefeated streak ends with loss to US
items.summary: The Socceroos have already qualified for the World Cup, with coach Tony Popovic hoping new players "surprise" him ahead of the finals.

items.title: Australian passport power revealed, as the US and UK hit record lows
items.summary: For the first time in 20 years, the United States' passport has fallen from the top ten most powerful in the world.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 15 October
items.summary: A daily five-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Military seizes power in Madagascar after president flees amid youth protests
items.summary: Gen Z-driven demonstrations erupted last month over water and power shortages, quickly escalating into an uprising over broader grievances.

items.title: Victorian government debates ground-breaking Treaty Bill
items.summary: The Victorian Government is debating a historic Statewide Treaty Bill, establishing Australia's first ever Treaty agreement between a state government and First Peoples in Victoria. If signed into law, the Treaty Bill will forge a path forward for First Peoples in Victoria to negotiate and influence the policy that affects community.

items.title: 'Mystified': Concern for thousands in Australia after Venezuela's surprise move
items.summary: The closure of Venezuela's embassy in Canberra follows the Nobel Peace Prize being awarded to Venezuela's opposition leader over the weekend. But are the two related?

items.title: 'The hunt for the nearest mechanic': NATO chief mocks 'broken' Russian submarine
items.summary: Russia's Black Sea Fleet rejected reports the diesel-powered submarine had suffered a serious malfunction.

items.title: What are rare earths, and why are the share prices of companies mining them surging?
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Kai Chen from MPC Markets about the rise on rare earths along with the rest of the day's sharemarket action.

items.title: Hamas' next move is unknown, but one person may 'hold the key' to a lasting peace in Gaza
items.summary: The first phase of a deeply complex peace process has begun. So what happens next?

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 14 October 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Middle East peace deal signed; so where to from here?
items.summary: World leaders have signed a historic Middle East deal at a summit in Egypt. It comes hours after Israel and Hamas exchanged detainees and hostages. Israel released nearly 2,000 Palestinians from Israeli prisons, and Gaza released the surviving Israeli hostages after two years in captivity.

items.title: Climate tipping points being crossed, scientists warn
items.summary: A large white coral reef containing important species and fossil traces has been discovered at a depth of more than 500 metres in the Gulf of Naples, in a rare discovery for the Mediterranean. But a new report suggests reefs like this might already be in danger, with global warming crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected and the world's coral reefs now in an almost irreversible die-off. It marks what scientists are describing as the first tipping point in climate-driven ecosystem collapse.

items.title: 'Concern' over prime minister and Opposition leader's phone numbers being leaked
items.summary: Anthony Albanese and Sussan Ley are among dozens of high-profile Australians whose numbers have been leaked.

items.title: 'I don't have words': Cape Verde erupts in celebration after historic World Cup qualification
items.summary: The island nation is set to become one of the smallest countries to participate in football's showpiece event.

items.title: 'Historic dawn': Key takeaways from Trump's speech at the Israeli parliament
items.summary: Trump announced a new era of peace, as Hamas freed the remaining hostages and Israel released nearly 2,000 prisoners and detainees.

items.title: The new threat to Australia's potato industry - what is it and how can we deal with it?
items.summary: Of all Australian states, Tasmania is the biggest producer of potatoes, and a lot of what's grown here goes into potato products you would know well – hot chips, hash browns and wedges among them. But a new virus detected in recent months is causing concern. Growers are optimistic it can be managed, stressing it doesn't pose a risk to human health.

items.title: ‘Historic exchange’: all Israeli hostages freed as Gaza peace talks continue
items.summary: All 20 surviving Israeli hostages have been released from Hamas captivity in Gaza in a historic exchange as part of the first phase of a Gaza peace plan. And nearly 2000 Palestinians have also been freed from Israeli prisons, with the majority headed back to the war-ravaged Palestinian enclave. United States President Donald Trump has claimed the Israel-Hamas war is over, but negotiations are set to continue in Egypt with long-term peace still far from secure.

items.title: 'Eating mostly brown food': The 'devastating' juggle faced by a rising number of Australians
items.summary: With one in seven Australians living below the poverty line, researchers and advocates say that COVID-era universal income is the solution.

items.title: The common way Australians have their data stolen — and what it's costing
items.summary: The average financial losses from cybercrimes, both for Australians and businesses, continue to rise annually.

items.title: New super changes for low income earners and high balances & how geopolitics is impacting markets
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Goncalves speaks with Daniel Martin from Alvia Asset Partners about the day's market news including the impact of geopolitics including the holding ceasefire in Gaza; plus hear from Treasurer Jim Chalmers as he addresses changes to superannuation.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 13 October
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: The changes to your superannuation in Treasurer Jim Chalmers' surprise announcement
items.summary: The government has responded to ongoing criticism, announcing half a dozen changes to the tax reforms they brought to the 2022 election.

items.title: Has your Qantas data been leaked? Here's what you can do
items.summary: A cybersecurity expert has warned scammers will employ both immediate and "long game" strategies to use the stolen data.

items.title: 'An all-time low': Why are Afghanistan and Pakistan fighting along their border?
items.summary: Pakistan has accused Afghanistan of sheltering militants behind a surge in attacks on its soil.

items.title: Donald Trump softens tone on China after tariff tensions flare
items.summary: Trump has taken a less confrontational approach in his latest social media post on trade tensions with China.

items.title: The miscarriage data gap and 'invisible loss' leaving Australian women behind
items.summary: A new report is calling for a national database on miscarriage to address ongoing invisibility around miscarriage and early pregnancy loss in Australia, particularly for First Nations women and in rural and regional communities. This comes as the government announced a $9.5 million funding package in May last year to improve awareness and support for early pregnancy loss.

items.title: 'I felt alone': Inside the 'invisible' loss one in three Australian women endure
items.summary: Organisations that help women through miscarriages are looking forward to seeing a national pregnancy loss register to address what they say is an invisibility around the true scale of the issue.

items.title: I asked a mortgage broker what median first home buyers can get with a 5% deposit (not much)
items.summary: First home buyers can get into the housing market with a 5 per cent deposit - but are there hidden pitfalls they may not be aware of? We asked an expert to crunch the numbers.

items.title: California sends ultraprocessed school meals to the sin bin
items.summary: California is to phase out certain ultraprocessed foods from school meals over the next decade under a first-in-the-nation law signed by Governor Gavin Newsom. Schools will have to start removing those foods from their menus by July 2029, and districts will be barred from selling them for breakfast or lunch by July 2035.

items.title: Not just magpies: The other birds swooping you this season — and why they do it
items.summary: Magpies may have perfected the art of swooping, but they're not the only Australian bird diving on unsuspecting humans this spring.

items.title: Casper takes a drug that helps him grow. But the treatment is controversial
items.summary: A controversial drug Australia had a key role in developing continues to bring hope - and frustration – for the short-statured community.

items.title: Clean-up begins in Philippines after at least eight killed in twin earthquakes
items.summary: Some residents in Mindanao slept outdoors in fear of aftershocks after 7.4 and 6.7-magnitude earthquakes struck off the coast on Friday.

items.title: Australia's potato capital is facing a threat never-before-seen in the country
items.summary: With eradication off the table, Australia is looking to New Zealand for lessons on how to manage potato mop top virus as planting begins in Tasmania.

items.title: Saving money and packing 'go bags': How Australians in the US are preparing for the worst
items.summary: With changes to visas and growing scrutiny of foreign nationals, Australians in the US say they feel uncertain about their futures.

items.title: Silver at highest since 1980 & how markets are reacting to Gaza peace deal
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Zoran Kresovic from Blueberry Markets about the day's market action, including how investors are feeling following the potential Gaza peace deal, the future for gold and the outlook for silver, which hit a near 45 year high.

items.title: The looming Europe travel change that will affect Australians
items.summary: New personal data collection rules are about to come into effect in Europe's Schengen area. Here's what you need to know.

items.title: How a 'deeply embedded' part of Australian culture could change forever
items.summary: Young Australians are leading this emerging generational shift, according to a new study.

items.title: Tsunami threat passes after powerful earthquake strikes Philippines
items.summary: A tsunami alert for the Philippines, Palau and Indonesia has been lifted following a magnitude 7.4 earthquake south of the Philippines.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 10 October 2025
items.summary: A daily news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Are Syria’s first post-Assad elections strengthening or weakening democracy?
items.summary: Syria's first parliamentary elections since the fall of Bashar al-Assad have sparked criticism for how they were run. The election was seen as a key step in the shift away from the al-Assad regime, but one that has sparked concerns about inclusivity and fairness under the country's new leaders. Syrians here in Australia say their relatives at home do not feel represented by the new Government.

items.title: What’s the Senate actually estimating? Ft. David Pocock
items.summary: The first senate estimates of the 48th Parliament have arrived – where the Albanese Labor Government and representatives from the Australian Public Service and government agencies are quizzed for up to 14 hours a day about pretty much anything. It’s tedious, it’s long, but it’s all about accountability, and Independent Senator for the ACT David Pocock takes us behind the scenes. Plus Bob Katter has a suggestion for the footy off-season, and Andrew Hastie has left the Coalition front bench.

items.title: 'It felt like home': Why generations of migrant Australians love the NPL
items.summary: Once the lifeblood of migrant communities, suburban football clubs are back on the national stage for the Australian Championship.

items.title: A Gaza peace deal signed; au revoir to yet another French PM; & Australia's new security alliance
items.summary: Hamas and Israel sign up for Phase One of Trump's new 20-point plan for peace in Gaza. France's revolving door on its prime ministerial office takes another spin. Plus Australia and PNG sign on to an expanded alliance for regional cooperation. And how desperate for $5,000 are you? Take a job at a haunted hotel desperate?

items.title: Gaza peace deal market impacts & Gemini crypto exchange enters Australia
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Robert Talevski to see how the Gaza peace deal has impacted markets; and Ricardo takes a look at Australia's crypto regulatory space with Gemini's Saad Ahmed.

items.title: New workplace laws aim to remove extra pain burden on parents arising from stillbirth
items.summary: Laws have been introduced into federal parliament to stop employers from scrapping leave entitlements when families face the tragedy of a stillbirth or death of their baby.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 9 October 2025
items.summary: A daily news wrap for English learners and people with disability.
